(2/2) Her thoughtful opinions and longtime friendship with the late Antonin Scalia serve as a reminder that we can disagree without being disagreeable. My thoughts and prayers are with the Ginsburg family during this difficult time.
(1/2) For nearly three decades, Ruth Bader Ginsburg served our country honorably, becoming just the second woman ever to be appointed to the Supreme Court.

Her judicial opinions on voting rights, gender discrimination, and same-sex marriage made this country stronger & will continue to ring out through the ages. She is a shining example of how one person can impact our world and truly make a difference. May her memory be a blessing.

Generations of women — my mother, myself, my sisters, my daughters — are indebted to her tenacity.

Decision by decision, Justice Ginsburg reaffirmed the ideals of our Constitution and our shared values of fairness, equality, and opportunity.

We mourn the loss of an American icon. Justice Ginsburg was a pioneer and a role model for women across America. She's the reason women like me not only believed we had a right to be in the workplace, but were guaranteed it. She won us equality, and then showed us how to succeed. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EiP-KZnXkAAVeZj.jpg

The loss of Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is an immense one. She was a tireless champion for justice and a fierce advocate for the rights of all people under the law. My thoughts are with her family and I join people across the nation in mourning her passing.

Only then, after we immerse ourselves in prayer, reflection and intention-setting, will we fully be ready to meet the coming moment. I am so grateful to be facing it with this beloved spiritual community. Gemar chatimah tovah! 23//

You want a Rosh Hashanah that tests your faith? Try losing RBG to start things off. You want to make 5781 a year of hope and joy? Try taking immense pride in the outsize accomplishments of this tiny Jew and vowing to make her proud. 22/

Amidst our tears, we realize we have no choice but to listen to her and to John Lewis and others we have lost in a moment of turmoil when we need them most, to study their ways, pick up their tools, and march on towards justice. 21/
“You don’t think my shoulders are big enough for you to stand on? I think you are afraid to hop on!  But I believe in you.” 20/
Reflecting on her astounding accomplishments, we realize that we can win in the end. We hear her beckoning to us and teasing us. 19/
Because in pausing to appreciate Ruth Bader Ginsburg fully, we see the importance of brilliant strategy and steely determination and good humor. 18/
Why can’t we just turn with anxiety and determination to the next fight, the fight over RBG’s replacement? 17/
Why must we breathe in the full measure of this person before we turn to the tragedy of her death at this incredible trough in the history of our nation? 16/
“I am with you and, indeed, you ARE me, we are one.” 15/

In the end, the justice-turned-icon, Notorious RBG, the most unlikely rock star, whose seemingly diminutive frailty was the falsest thing about her, hiding a well-worked body, a will of steel, that galloping mind, and a glint in her eye that told every girl:

14/
A teacher-justice, who crafted these decisions in a manner not only meant to make law in the moment, but to teach future justices and the general public how law functions in the real world. 13/

For nearly three decades, a Supreme Court justice who hammered out brave decisions and dissents that shone the light towards the future of dignity and justice for all that we all long for and, on these high holy days, we reaffirm our faith is a possible and necessary future. 12/
Unlike Trump, so intent on dominating, Clinton chose a 60-year-old, because this titan of women’s and all human’s rights was so obviously the best choice imaginable.  11/

The appeals court judge who was not President Bill Clinton’s first choice to join the Court but who, with her devoted husband, blew him away with her brilliance & charismatic anti-charisma – her directness, lack of artifice, legal brilliance so plain that it was sun-like. 10/

The very architect of the assault against legal discrimination against women who, following in the footsteps of Thurgood Marshall the lawyer not the justice, carefully disassembled the formal wall excluding women from all manner of rights brick by well-chosen brick. 9/
Please pause on that. 8/
A person thus pushed into teaching instead, and given the space for advocacy. The system, by discriminating against her, set up a mighty campaign to fell discrimination. 7/
A brilliant lawyer no law firm would hire, because she had ovaries and, heaven forfend, was a mother. 6/

A tiny person. A shy person. A modest person. A woman who put her husband’s career first. A young wife who nursed her husband and helped him with his school work, only turning to hers in the middle of the night. A woman who, nevertheless, finished at the top of her class. 5/
But I want to suggest that instead of fuming over Mitch McConnell and all of his blatant hypocrisy, or fretting about or gaming out what is to come, instead of all that let us consider this woman. 4/
When people die, it is hard to step back from the moment and circumstances of their death in order to imbibe the lessons of their lives, isn’t it? Especially in circumstances like this. 3/
I want to ask you to resist what may be your first impulse over the loss of Ruth Bader Ginsburg – the political horror of it. 2/
With an evening to reflect, there are a few more words I'd like to share about Justice Ginsburg. 1/

For those despairing over Justice Ginsburg’s loss & those considering all that her death means for our country & highest court, I am choosing to carry the belief in our country & the hope of these students with me every day until Election Day and thereafter. I hope you will, too.

And yet in the immediacy of that loss, I was struck by the community the students had brought together, the cause of justice they believe in, and value they place on our most basic civic responsibility – the vote.

As they honored his life, we learned of the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg. The world had just lost a woman who blazed a trail for gender equality and used her brilliance and her love of the law to seek justice for all people.
As the teens honored him, they spoke of the hope they have for our country, the belief they have in our shared future, and they implored us – the adults with a vote and a voice – to use it.

Last night, I attended an event organized by teenagers, most of whom cannot yet vote, to honor the life of Congressman John Lewis. In Veteran’s Park in Orange County, they spoke of his legacy, his fight for voting rights, & the impact he, even as a teenager, was able to have. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EiS_IpnXsAAno75.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EiS_KMYWAAAdOOj.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EiS_SxXXcAIUv1a.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EiS_WyRXcAA1sdH.jpg
